query: What are the most effective ways to manage uncropped field margins on European farmland to support bumblebees?
relevant_summary: Uncropped field margins can be managed in several ways to support bumblebees on European farmland. Sowing margins with an agricultural nectar and pollen mix has been shown to attract more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy, or cropped margins [18]. In the first year, a mix of agricultural forage plants, including legumes, can attract a higher number of bumblebees than a perennial wildflower mix [18]. However, these margins may need to be re-sown every few years as their value to bumblebees degrades over time [18]. Sowing margins with a native wildflower seed mix also supports a higher abundance and species richness of foraging bumblebees compared to cropped, grassy, or naturally regenerated margins [19]. Perennial leguminous herbs within these seed mixes are particularly important for long-tongued bumblebee species [19]. Leaving field margins to regenerate naturally can result in more bumblebees than cropped margins, but the value of this approach is not consistent from year to year and is dependent on thistle species, which are often considered weeds [20]. There is no evidence on the effects of these management practices on solitary bees [18, 19, 20].

query: How do different management approaches for uncropped arable field margins in Europe, such as sowing mixes versus natural regeneration, compare in their benefits for bumblebees?
relevant_summary:
Five replicated trials in Europe showed that sowing uncropped arable field margins with an agricultural nectar and pollen mix, particularly those containing perennial leguminous flowering plants, attracted significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated margins (18). Similarly, five replicated trials in the UK indicated that margins sown with native wild flower seed mixes supported a higher abundance of foraging bumblebees compared to naturally regenerated uncropped margins (19). One small trial, however, recorded the same number of bee species on both wildflower sown and naturally regenerated strips (19).

Three replicated trials found that a mix of agricultural forage plants attracted a greater number of bumblebees than a perennial wildflower mix, at least in the first year (18). Conversely, one small replicated trial showed that common long-tongued bumblebee species strongly preferred perennial wildflower seed mixes over a mix of annual forage plants (19). Perennial leguminous herbs in wildflower seed mixtures were noted as important forage sources for bumblebees, especially long-tongued species (19).

Regarding naturally regenerated margins, four replicated trials in the UK found more bumblebees foraging on these compared to cropped margins (20). However, the value of these margins for bees was not consistent from year to year and often relied on thistle species considered to be pernicious weeds (20). A small replicated trial found that neither the abundance nor diversity of bumblebees was higher on naturally regenerated margins than on cropped margins (20).

Finally, three trials in the UK found that margins sown with agricultural legume plants degraded in their value to bumblebees and would require re-sowing every few years (18). For all three management approaches—sowing with agricultural mixes, sowing with wildflower mixes, and natural regeneration—no evidence was captured on the effects on solitary bees (18, 19, 20).

query: How does the effectiveness of planting phacelia (Phacelia tanacetifolia) as a floral resource for wild bees vary by location?
relevant_summary: Ten trials in Europe and North America found substantial numbers of wild bees, particularly bumblebees, foraging on Phacelia tanacetifolia, with six of these trials recording between eight and 35 foraging bee species (17). However, one replicated trial in Greece indicated that phacelia is not very attractive to wild bees in that location (17).

query: What are the documented benefits of controlling or excluding competitor or predator species from bee nesting sites?
relevant_summary: Eleven replicated trials have recorded solitary bees in nest boxes being attacked by parasites or predators (47). Rates of mortality and parasitism have been measured in 10 studies, with mortality rates ranging from 13% to 56% (47). Two replicated trials in California, USA, showed that introduced European earwigs and introduced European leafcutter bee species use drilled wooden nest boxes, with one trial showing these introduced species occupied the boxes more commonly than native bees (47).

  "action_title": "Provide artificial nest sites for solitary bees",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
We have captured 30 replicated trials of nest boxes for solitary bees in 10 countries, including Europe, North and South America and Asia. Twenty-nine of these trials showed occupancy by bees. Many species of solitary bee readily nest in the boxes, including some species considered endangered in a study on farmland in Germany, oil-collecting species of the genus Centris in South America and a recently discovered species in lowland tropical forest in Costa Rica. One trial in temperate forest in Canada recorded no bees using nest boxes.
A set of replicated experiments in Germany estimated that four medium to large European species of solitary bee have a foraging range of 150 to 600 m, so nest boxes must be within this distance of foraging resources.
Twenty-three replicated trials have shown nest boxes of cut hollow stems or tubes being occupied by solitary bees. Eleven trials demonstrated occupation of blocks of wood drilled with holes. Two trials in Neotropical secondary forest (one in Brazil, one in Mexico) showed that particular solitary bee species will nest in wooden boxes, without stems or confining walls inside.
Two replicated trials have compared reproductive success in different nest box designs. One showed that reed stem and wooden grooved-board nest boxes produced more bees/nest than four other types. Nest boxes with plastic-lined holes, or plastic or paper tubes were much less productive, due to parasitism or mould. The other, a small trial, found nests of the oil-collecting bee Centris analis in Brazil were more productive in cardboard straws placed in drilled wooden holes than in grooved wooden boards stacked together.
Three trials on agricultural land, one on a carpenter bee in India, one on a range of species in Germany and one on species of Osmia in the USA, have shown that the number of occupied solitary bee nests can double over three years with repeated nest box provision at a given site.
One small replicated trial compared populations of solitary bees in blueberry fields in the USA with and without nest boxes over three years. The estimated number of foraging Osmia bees had increased in fields with nest boxes, compared to fields without nest boxes.
Eleven replicated trials have recorded solitary bees in nest boxes being attacked by parasites or predators. Rates of mortality and parasitism have been measured in 10 studies. Mortality rates range from 13% mortality for cavity-nesting bees and wasps combined in Germany (2% were successfully parasitized), or 2% of bee brood cells attacked in shade coffee and cacao plantations in central Sulawesi, Indonesia, to 36% parasitism and 20% other mortality (56% mortality overall) for the subtropical carpenter bee Xylocopa fenestrata in India.
Two replicated trials of the use of drilled wooden nest boxes by bees in California, USA, showed that introduced European earwigs Forficula auricularia and introduced European leafcutter bee species use the boxes. In one trial, these introduced species more commonly occupied the boxes than native bees.
A small trial tested three soil-filled nest boxes for the mining bee Andrena flavipes in the UK, but they were not occupied."

query: What actions can be taken to support wild bee populations in urban areas and along infrastructure corridors like roads and power lines?
relevant_summary:
In urban areas, planting parks and gardens with appropriate flowers, such as bee forage or native plants, has been found to increase the number of wild bee species and individuals (1). One study on green infrastructure found that while green roofs had lower butterfly species richness and abundance than urban parks, butterfly abundance was higher on older, larger green roofs with more nectar plant species (3837).

Along infrastructure corridors, several actions have been shown to benefit insect populations. Restoring or maintaining species-rich grassland along road and railway verges, particularly by sowing native wildflowers, can lead to a higher species richness and diversity of butterflies and moths (3854). Similarly, stopping the use of herbicides on pavements and road verges and restoring roadside prairies has been found to increase butterfly species richness and abundance (3899). Managing land under power lines, for instance through mechanical cutting, has also been shown to increase butterfly species richness and abundance (3855).

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Taiwan found that green roofs had a lower species richness of butterflies than urban parks.

POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Abundance (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Taiwan found that green roofs had a lower abundance of butterflies than urban parks, but the abundance was higher on older green roofs with more nectar plant species in a larger area.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

Richness/diversity (2 studies): One replicated, paired, site comparison study in the USA found that restored roadside prairies where herbicide application was restricted had a greater species richness of butterflies than verges dominated by non-native weeds and grasses with no restrictions on herbicide application. Eight studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of restoring or maintaining species-rich grassland along road or railway verges. Three studies were in the USA and one was in each of Germany, the UK, Finland, Poland, and Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (6 studies): Four replicated, site comparison studies (including one paired study) in Germany, the UK, the USA and Finland found that restored roadside prairies, verges sown with native wildflowers, with more butterfly species’ larval food plants, with more species of plants and with more plants in flower had a higher species richness and diversity of butterflies, day-flying moths, burnet moths and meadow-specialist moths than verges dominated by non-native vegetation or with fewer butterfly species’ larval food plants, fewer plant species, and fewer plants in flower. One replicated, site comparison study in Canada found that road verges and land under power lines managed by mowing once or twice a year, or not at all, had a similar species richness of butterflies to remnant prairies. One replicated, site comparison study in Poland found that wide road verges had a higher species richness of butterflies than narrow road verges.

POPULATION RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Abundance (5 studies): Two of three replicated, site comparison studies (including one paired study) in the UK, the USA and Finland found that restored roadside prairies and verges sown with more butterfly species’ larval food plants had a greater abundance of butterflies and burnet moths than verges dominated by non-native vegetation or with fewer butterfly species’ larval food plants. One replicated, site comparison study in Canada found that road verges and land under power lines managed by mowing once or twice a year, or not at all, had a similar abundance of butterflies to remnant prairies. One replicated, site comparison study in Poland found that wide road verges had a greater abundance of butterflies than narrow road verges.

The other study found more dead butterflies and moths on roads with tall meadow verges than on roads with frequently mown, non-native, short grass verges or wooded verges. This study also found more dead butterflies and moths on roads with habitat in the central reservation than on roads without habitat in the central reservation. One replicated, site comparison study in Poland found that less frequently mown road verges, and verges mown later in the summer, had fewer dead butterflies than verges which were mown more frequently or earlier in the summer.
Condition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that monarch caterpillars living on road verges mown once or twice a year had a similar number of parasites to caterpillars living in mown and unmown prairies.

Six studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of managing land under power lines for butterflies and moths. Two studies were in each of the USA and Finland, and one was in each of the UK and Canada.

Richness/diversity (3 studies): Two replicated, site comparison studies (including one paired study) in Finland found that land under power lines managed by mechanical cutting had a higher species richness of butterflies than unmanaged land, and butterfly species richness was highest 2–4 years after scrub and trees were cleared. POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Abundance (6 studies): One of two replicated, site comparison studies (including one paired study) in Finland and Canada found that land under power lines managed by mechanical cutting had a higher abundance of butterflies than unmanaged land. The other study found that land under power lines and on road verges managed by mowing had a lower abundance of pearl crescent and northern pearl crescent butterflies, and a similar abundance of other butterflies, to those left unmown. BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

query: What are the documented outcomes and challenges of rearing bumblebees in captivity for reintroduction?
relevant_summary:
Captive rearing of bumblebees has shown varied success and presented several challenges (50, 52). One trial found that over four years of artificial rearing, the weight of *Bombus terrestris* queens gradually decreased (50). Efforts to rear declining North American bumblebee species have had mixed results; while some species were successfully reared to adults, in other cases, larvae died before reaching adulthood (50). The reproductive success of captive colonies is influenced by their pollen diet, with freshly frozen pollen and pollen with higher protein content yielding better results (50). Artificial light regimes and specific hibernation conditions, such as temperature and duration, have been shown to affect egg-laying and colony formation, although hibernation can sometimes result in smaller colonies (50).

When laboratory-reared colonies were reintroduced to the wild, the outcomes were inconsistent (52). In some trials, the number of new queens produced was very low or zero, while other trials reported good production of new queens (52). A significant challenge in reintroduction is social parasitism by cuckoo bees, with rates varying from 0% to as high as 79% in different trials (52). The success of supplementary feeding for colonies in the field has also been inconsistent, with one study showing improved reproductive success and another finding no increase in colony productivity (52).

{
  "action_id": "50",
  "action_title": "Rear declining bumblebees in captivity",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
We have captured 22 trials from 13 countries documenting captive rearing of bumblebee colonies by confining mated queens alone (eight trials), with one or more bumblebee workers (seven trials), honey bee workers (one trial), male bumblebee pupae (three trials) or following anaesthetisation with CO2 (four trials). One trial found that over four years of artificial rearing, Bombus terrestris queens gradually decreased in weight.
Three trials have tried to rear North American bumblebees now declining or thought to be declining. Two induced spring queens of the half-black bumblebee B. vagans to rear adults in captivity, one trial induced queen yellow-banded bumblebees B. terricola (attempted in all three trials) and red-belted bumblebees B. rufocinctus (only attempted in one trial) to rear adults in captivity. All three trials tried to rear the yellow bumblebee B. fervidus and in all cases the queens laid eggs but the larvae died before becoming adults. One trial found the same pattern for the rusty-patched bumblebee and the American bumblebee B. pensylvanicus. One study reports rearing the large garden bumblebee B. ruderatus, a Biodiversity Action Plan species in the UK.
Two trials have reported laboratory rearing of a pocket-making bumblebee, the Neotropical B. atratus.
Three replicated trials demonstrated that the pollen diet of captively reared bumblebees influences reproductive success. In one trial, buff-tailed bumblebee B. terrestris colonies fed on freshly frozen pollen produced larger queens that survived better and produced larger colonies themselves than colonies fed on dried, frozen pollen. Two replicated trials demonstrated that B. terrestris workers can produce more offspring when fed types of pollen with a higher protein content.
Two replicated experiments showed that an artificial light regime of eight hours light, 16 hours darkness, can reduce the time taken for artificially reared queen B. terrestris to lay eggs, relative to rearing in constant darkness.
We have captured two replicated trials examining the effect of different artificial hibernation regimes in B. terrestris. One showed that hibernation of queens at 4-5°C for 45 days enhanced egg-laying and colony formation rates, but hibernated queens produced smaller colonies than non-hibernated queens. The second showed that queens should weigh more than 0.6 g (wet weight) and be hibernated for four months or less to have a good chance of surviving."
}

query: What are the known risks and control methods associated with using commercial bee colonies for pollination?

relevant_summary.erroneous_summary: Parasites and pathogens are a known risk when commercially rearing and managing solitary bee populations for pollination, and various control methods have been developed (54). There are also risks associated with feeding bees artificial diets. One replicated trial showed high larval mortality in Osmia cornuta when they were reared on artificial pollen-based diets, which included pollen collected by honey bees. Another trial found that Megachile rotundata either died or had low pre-pupal weight when reared on synthetic pollen substitutes (54). However, M. rotundata could be successfully reared on an artificial diet that was based on honey bee-collected pollen (54). In times of pollen scarcity, stingless bees (Scaptotrigona postica) can be fed pollen substitutes such as brewer's yeast or a mixture with 25% pollen collected by honey bees (33). To avoid damaging the brood during honey extraction, a wooden hive with separate, different-shaped honey and brood chambers can be used (33). Additionally, brood growth in traditional log hives was found to be higher than in box hives with internal volumes exceeding 14 litres, leading to a recommendation for smaller box hives (33).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"risks and control methods associated with using commercial bee colonies for pollination"}

  "action_id": "33",
  "action_title": "Replace honey-hunting with apiculture",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

One study reported that a programme to enhance take-up of stingless beekeeping in southern Mexico increased the number of managed colonies in the area.
Five trials contributed to scientific improvement of stingless beekeeping methods. Two controlled trials showed that either brewer's yeast (one trial) or a mix with 25% pollen collected by honey bees Apis mellifera (one trial) can be used as a pollen substitute to feed Scaptotrigona postica in times of pollen scarcity. A study on the island of Tobago found a wooden hive design with separate, different-shaped honey and brood chambers allowed honey to be extracted without damaging the brood. One trial showed that 50 g of comb with mature pupae is enough to start a new daughter colony of S. mexicana. One trial found brood growth was higher in traditional log hives than in box hives with internal volumes exceeding 14 litres, and recommended smaller box hives.
We have captured no clear evidence about whether these activities help conserve bees or enhance native bee populations."

query: How does the effectiveness of managing hedges for bees in Scotland compare to managing land under power lines for bees in the USA?
relevant_summary: One replicated controlled trial showed that hedges managed under the Scottish Rural Stewardship scheme do not attract more nest-searching or foraging queen bumblebees in spring than conventionally managed hedgerows (15). One replicated trial in Maryland, USA found more bee species under power lines managed as scrub than in equivalent areas of annually mown grassland (31). No evidence was captured for the effects of managing land under power lines to benefit wildlife on farmland wildlife (99).

  "action_title": "Manage land under power lines for butterflies and moths",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of managing land under power lines for butterflies and moths. Two studies were in each of the USA and Finland, and one was in each of the UK and Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (3 studies): Two replicated, site comparison studies (including one paired study) in Finland found that land under power lines managed by mechanical cutting had a higher species richness of butterflies than unmanaged land, and butterfly species richness was highest 2–4 years after scrub and trees were cleared. One replicated, site comparison study in Canada found that the species richness of butterflies was similar under power lines and on road verges mown once or twice a year, or left unmown.

POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Abundance (6 studies): One of two replicated, site comparison studies (including one paired study) in Finland and Canada found that land under power lines managed by mechanical cutting had a higher abundance of butterflies than unmanaged land. The other study found that land under power lines and on road verges managed by mowing had a lower abundance of pearl crescent and northern pearl crescent butterflies, and a similar abundance of other butterflies, to those left unmown. Two of three site comparison studies (including two replicated studies) in the USA, the UK and Finland found that the time since management under power lines did not affect the abundance of Karner blue butterflies or small pearl-bordered fritillaries, but chequered skipper abundance was higher in areas cleared ≤2 years ago than in areas cut ≥4 years earlier. The other study found that power lines cleared of trees and scrub 2–4 years earlier had a higher abundance of butterflies than power lines cleared 1 year or 6–8 years earlier. Two site comparison studies in the USA found that land under power lines managed by cutting or herbicide application, and by mowing or cutting, had a similar abundance of Karner blue butterflies and six other butterfly species, but the abundance of frosted elfin was higher under power lines managed by mowing than those managed by cutting.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Use (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in the UK reported that pearl-bordered fritillaries used areas under power lines where scrub had been cleared one or two years earlier, but not under power lines cleared three or more years ago."

query: What is the extent of evidence on the success of translocating bees or augmenting small populations to improve genetic diversity?
relevant_summary: One trial in Brazil found that regularly introducing inseminated queens could maintain genetic diversity in small, isolated populations of stingless bees (56). Another study in India showed that translocating carpenter bees during their immature stages could establish a new population, but very few adult bees remained when they were moved to a new location (55). There were no studies found that looked at the effects of introducing mated females to increase genetic diversity in butterflies and moths (3912).

query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of different sown floral mixes on agricultural land for wild bees?
relevant_summary: Fourteen trials in Europe and North America have recorded substantial numbers of wild bees foraging on perennial or annual sown flowering plants in the agricultural environment (17). Ten trials have monitored bees foraging on patches sown with a high proportion of phacelia, with all but one finding substantial numbers of foraging wild (non-Apis) bees, particularly bumblebees (17). One replicated controlled trial in the UK showed that planted perennial leguminous herbs were more attractive to bumblebees in landscapes with a greater proportion of arable farming (17). Four replicated trials showed that field margins sown with perennial leguminous flowering plants attract significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy or cropped field margins (18). Three replicated trials showed that a mix of agricultural forage plants including legumes attracts greater numbers of bumblebees than a perennial wildflower mix, at least in the first year (18). Three trials in the UK found evidence that margins sown with agricultural legume plants degrade in their value to bumblebees and would need to be re-sown every few years (18). One trial showed that planted patches of bigleaf lupine in commercial apple orchards significantly enhanced the reproductive success of blue orchard mason bees (17). However, one trial in the Netherlands showed that bee numbers and species richness are not higher in farmland 50-1,500 m away from planted flower patches (17). Two trials in Germany found no or relatively few species of solitary bee nesting on set-aside fields sown with phacelia or clover (17), and no evidence has been captured on the effects of field margin management on solitary bees (18).

query: What evidence exists for creating or managing land to provide nesting sites for ground-nesting bees?
relevant_summary: One replicated controlled trial in Germany and four small trials have shown that artificially exposed areas of bare soil can be successfully colonised by ground-nesting solitary bees and wasps in the first or second year (13). We have captured no evidence for the effect of creating areas of bare ground on bee populations or communities on a larger scale (13). Ten studies (nine replicated trials and a review of studies) from Germany, Poland and the UK of solitary bee nest boxes all showed the nest boxes were readily used by bees (80). Two replicated studies found the local population size or number of emerging red mason bees increased when nest boxes were provided (80). One replicated trial in Germany showed that the number of occupied solitary bee nests almost doubled over three years with repeated nest box provision at a given site (80). A replicated study from Poland found the highest production of red mason bees per nest was from nesting materials of reed stems or wood (80). Eleven replicated trials of bumblebee nest boxes have shown that several different types of nest box are acceptable to bumblebees, including wooden or brick and tile boxes at the ground surface, underground tin, wooden or terracotta boxes and boxes attached to trees (48). However, three replicated trials since 1989 in the UK have shown very low uptake rates (0-2.5%) of various nest box designs (not including underground nest boxes), while seven trials in previous decades in the UK, USA or Canada, and one recent trial in the USA, showed overall uptake rates between 10% and 48% (48). Two replicated trials that tested bumblebee nest boxes both found very low uptake, 2% or less (80). Nest boxes entirely buried 5-10 cm underground, with a 30-80 cm long entrance pipe, are generally the most effective type for bumblebees, with seven replicated trials in the USA, Canada or the UK having found between 6% and 58% occupancy (48). We have captured no evidence for the effects of providing nest boxes on bumblebee populations (48).

query: What actions have been studied to mitigate the direct impacts of pesticides on wild bees?
relevant_summary: One replicated trial in the USA suggests that the number of foraging bees on squash farms is not affected by the responsible use of pesticides [27]. Four replicated trials in Europe compared farmland meadows managed extensively with conventionally farmed meadows or silage fields [22]. Two of these trials found enhanced numbers and diversity of wild bees on meadows with a delayed first cut and little agrochemical use [22]. The other two trials found no difference in bee diversity or abundance between conventional meadows and meadows with reduced fertilizer use or cutting intensity [22].

query: In the USA, what factors have been shown to affect the success of artificial nesting sites for solitary bees?
relevant_summary: In the USA, a study in blueberry fields indicated an increase in foraging Osmia bees in fields with nest boxes (47). The number of occupied nests for Osmia bees in the USA can double over a three-year period with continuous nest box provision (47). However, in California, introduced European earwigs and leafcutter bees have been observed using these boxes, sometimes more frequently than native bees (47). Studies conducted in Europe have identified additional factors influencing the success of artificial nests. For instance, it is recommended that nest boxes be positioned within 150 to 600 meters of foraging resources (47, 80). The choice of nesting material is also crucial, with one study indicating that reed stem and wooden grooved-board nest boxes yield more bees compared to other designs. Another study found that reed stems or wood resulted in higher bee production (47, 80). In contrast, designs featuring plastic-lined holes or tubes were less effective due to problems with parasitism or mould (47).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"factors affecting success of artificial nesting sites for solitary bees in the USA"}

  "action_title": "Provide artificial nest sites for solitary bees",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
We have captured 30 replicated trials of nest boxes for solitary bees in 10 countries, including Europe, North and South America and Asia. Twenty-nine of these trials showed occupancy by bees. Many species of solitary bee readily nest in the boxes, including some species considered endangered in a study on farmland in Germany, oil-collecting species of the genus Centris in South America and a recently discovered species in lowland tropical forest in Costa Rica. One trial in temperate forest in Canada recorded no bees using nest boxes.
A set of replicated experiments in Germany estimated that four medium to large European species of solitary bee have a foraging range of 150 to 600 m, so nest boxes must be within this distance of foraging resources.
Twenty-three replicated trials have shown nest boxes of cut hollow stems or tubes being occupied by solitary bees. Eleven trials demonstrated occupation of blocks of wood drilled with holes. Two trials in Neotropical secondary forest (one in Brazil, one in Mexico) showed that particular solitary bee species will nest in wooden boxes, without stems or confining walls inside.
Two replicated trials have compared reproductive success in different nest box designs. One showed that reed stem and wooden grooved-board nest boxes produced more bees/nest than four other types. Nest boxes with plastic-lined holes, or plastic or paper tubes were much less productive, due to parasitism or mould. The other, a small trial, found nests of the oil-collecting bee Centris analis in Brazil were more productive in cardboard straws placed in drilled wooden holes than in grooved wooden boards stacked together.
Three trials on agricultural land, one on a carpenter bee in India, one on a range of species in Germany and one on species of Osmia in the USA, have shown that the number of occupied solitary bee nests can double over three years with repeated nest box provision at a given site.

Eleven replicated trials have recorded solitary bees in nest boxes being attacked by parasites or predators. Rates of mortality and parasitism have been measured in 10 studies. Mortality rates range from 13% mortality for cavity-nesting bees and wasps combined in Germany (2% were successfully parasitized), or 2% of bee brood cells attacked in shade coffee and cacao plantations in central Sulawesi, Indonesia, to 36% parasitism and 20% other mortality (56% mortality overall) for the subtropical carpenter bee Xylocopa fenestrata in India.

query: What are the documented outcomes of practicing wildlife-friendly or low-intensity gardening for bees in urban areas?
relevant_summary: A study in a UK city revealed that domestic gardens with lower intensity management, which includes factors like garden tidiness and pesticide use, had a higher number of bumblebee species (2). However, the same study noted that solitary bees were not impacted by this lower intensity of management (2). In contrast, gardens that did not use insecticides and herbicides were found to have a greater abundance of butterflies (3834, 3900).

query: What is the state of the evidence for wild bee conservation when restoring different habitat types like grassland, heathland, and forest?
relevant_summary: For heathland restoration, two replicated trials in Dorset indicated that long-term restoration of dry lowland heath can restore a bee community similar to that on ancient heaths, while another small trial of early-stage lowland heath restoration did not have an adverse effect on bumblebee diversity (9). There was no evidence found on interventions to conserve bees on upland heath or moorland (9). In relation to grassland, three small trials found that restored species-rich grasslands had similar flower-visiting insect communities to paired ancient species-rich grasslands (8). In addition, one replicated controlled trial in Scotland showed that species-rich grassland managed under agri-environment schemes attracted more nest-searching queen bumblebees but fewer foraging queens in the spring than unmanaged grassland (8). When restoring habitat along watercourses, one replicated, paired site comparison from the USA found similar numbers of bees and bee species, but different bee communities, in restored and remnant sites (1408). In the same study, bee visitation rates to native flowers did not differ between restored and remnant sites (1408). No evidence was found for the effects of conserving old buildings and structures suitable for nesting wild bees (4). Four replicated trials in Europe have shown enhanced diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees on land managed under various European agri-environment schemes, relative to conventionally-managed fields or field margins (24). However, four other replicated trials in Europe found that the number of bees and/or bee species is not enhanced on land managed under agri-environment schemes (24). Furthermore, four replicated trials in Europe that compared farmland meadows managed extensively with conventionally farmed meadows or silage fields found that two showed enhanced numbers and diversity of wild bees on meadows with a delayed first cut and little agrochemical use, while the other two found no difference in bee diversity or abundance (22). No relevant evidence was found for forest habitats.

query: In Europe, what is the evidence for the effectiveness of agri-environment schemes for wild bees, and how does this vary between locations?
relevant_summary: Four replicated trials in Europe (in Switzerland, Germany, the Netherlands, and Scotland) indicated an enhanced diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees on land managed under agri-environment schemes compared to conventionally managed areas (24). However, four other replicated trials in Europe (in the Netherlands, Spain, and England) found no enhancement in the number of bees or bee species on land under similar schemes (24). On a broader landscape scale, two replicated trials in the UK found that bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland managed under these schemes (24). A UK study mentioned in a review of agri-environment schemes also found that these schemes had a local, but not a landscape-scale, effect on bee numbers (700). A review of ten studies from three European countries on invertebrates found that six studies showed that agri-environment schemes maintained or had little to no effect on bee colony growth, invertebrate diversity, abundance, or species richness, while five studies found increases in abundance or species richness for some invertebrates (700).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"effectiveness of agri-environment schemes for wild bees in Europe"}

relevant_summary: Two of four replicated trials in Europe found that meadows with a delayed first cut and little agrochemical use had enhanced numbers and diversity of wild bees, while two other trials found no difference in bee diversity or abundance between conventional meadows and those with reduced fertilizer use or cutting intensity (22). In contrast, four other replicated trials in Europe found no enhancement in the number of bees or bee species on land managed under agri-environment schemes (24). On a wider landscape scale, two replicated trials in the UK found that bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland managed under agri-environment schemes (24).

Twelve studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of reducing management intensity on permanent grasslands. Seven studies were in Switzerland, three were in the UK, and one was in each of Greece and Germany.

Community composition (2 studies): Two replicated studies (including one controlled study and one site comparison study) in Switzerland found that the composition of butterfly communities differed between low-input and intensively managed grasslands. The other study found that less intensively managed grassland had a similar abundance of moths to more intensively managed grassland. BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

query: What factors are known to influence the occupancy and productivity of artificial nest sites provided for solitary bees?
relevant_summary:
Several factors are known to influence the occupancy and productivity of artificial nest sites for solitary bees. The location of nest boxes is important, and they should be placed within the foraging range of the bees, which for some European species is between 150 to 600 meters from resources (47, 80). The design and material of the nest site also play a significant role. Many species of solitary bee readily nest in cut hollow stems, tubes, or blocks of wood with drilled holes (47). In terms of productivity, one trial found that reed stem and wooden grooved-board nest boxes produced more bees than other designs, while plastic-lined holes or tubes were less productive due to issues with parasitism and mould (47). Another small trial noted that cardboard straws within drilled wooden holes were more productive for a specific bee species than grooved wooden boards (47). A study in Poland also found that reed stems or wood resulted in the highest production for red mason bees (80).

The presence of parasites, predators, and mould can negatively impact productivity, with studies recording mortality rates ranging from 13% to 56% (47). One trial specifically showed that excluding ants from nesting sites increased the production of offspring (46). Additionally, introduced species, such as European earwigs and certain leafcutter bees, may occupy the nest boxes, in some cases more commonly than native bees (47).

Despite these challenges, repeated provision of nest boxes at a site can lead to an increase in the number of occupied nests over time, with some studies showing numbers doubling over three years (47, 80). One trial found that the estimated number of foraging bees increased in fields with nest boxes compared to those without (47). While many trials have shown successful occupation, one trial in a temperate forest in Canada recorded no bees using the provided nest boxes (47), and another small trial in the UK found that soil-filled nest boxes were not occupied by the target mining bee species (47). Occupancy rates, when reported, have been noted to be between 1% and 26% of the available cavities (80).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"factors influencing occupancy and productivity of artificial nest sites for solitary bees"}

query: What unintended negative consequences or limitations have been identified when providing artificial nest boxes for bees?
relevant_summary:
Several unintended negative consequences and limitations have been identified with the provision of artificial nest boxes for bees. Parasitism and predation are potential negative consequences of providing artificial nest boxes (47). Mortality rates from these causes have been measured at between 13% and 56% (47). Additionally, some nest box designs, such as those with plastic-lined holes or plastic/paper tubes, have been found to be less productive due to issues with parasitism or mould (47). Another unintended consequence is the occupation of nest boxes by non-native species, which in some cases, used the boxes more commonly than native bees (47).

A significant limitation is the low uptake or occupancy rate of the nest boxes (48, 80). For bumblebees, very low uptake rates of 0-2.5% have been recorded in several UK trials (48, 80). Similarly, some trials for solitary bees have shown no occupancy at all (47). Furthermore, for bumblebees, there is no evidence to suggest that providing nest boxes has a positive effect on their populations (48). Commonly marketed wooden surface or above-ground nest boxes are not the most effective designs for bumblebees and have resulted in occupancy rates as low as 0-1.5% in some UK studies (48).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"unintended negative consequences or limitations of artificial nest boxes for bees"}

  "action_title": "Provide artificial nest sites for bumblebees",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

We have captured 11 replicated trials of bumblebee nest boxes. Several different types of nest box have been shown to be acceptable to bumblebees, including wooden or brick and tile boxes at the ground surface, underground tin, wooden or terracotta boxes and boxes attached to trees.

 

Three replicated trials since 1989 in the UK have shown very low uptake rates (0-2.5%) of various nest box designs (not including underground nest boxes), while seven trials in previous decades in the UK, USA or Canada, and one recent trial in the USA, showed overall uptake rates between 10% and 48%.

 

Wooden surface or above ground nest boxes of the kind currently marketed for wildlife gardening are not the most effective design. Eight studies test this type of nest box. Five (pre-1978, USA or Canada) find 10-40% occupancy. Three (post-1989, UK) find very low occupancy of 0-1.5%. The four replicated trials that have directly compared wooden surface nest boxes with other types all report that underground, false underground or aerial boxes are more readily occupied.

 

Nest boxes entirely buried 5-10 cm underground, with a 30-80 cm long entrance pipe, are generally the most effective. Seven replicated trials in the USA, Canada or the UK have tested underground nest boxes and found between 6% and 58% occupancy. 

 

We have captured no evidence for the effects of providing nest boxes on bumblebee populations."
}

{
  "action_id": "80",
  "action_title": "Provide nest boxes for bees (solitary bees or bumblebees)",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Ten studies (nine replicated trials and a review of studies) from Germany, Poland and the UK of solitary bee nest boxes all showed the nest boxes were readily used by bees. Two replicated studies found the local population size or number of emerging red mason bees increased when nest boxes were provided. One replicated trial in Germany showed that the number of occupied solitary bee nests almost doubled over three years with repeated nest box provision at a given site.
Two replicated trials tested bumblebee nest boxes and both found very low uptake, 2% or less.
Occupancy rates of solitary bee nest boxes, where reported (two replicated studies), were between 1 and 26% of available cavities. Five studies (four replicated trials and a review of studies) report the number of bee species found in the nest boxes – between 4.6 and 33 species.
One replicated study from Germany found nest boxes should be placed 150-600 m from forage resources (Gathmann & Tscharntke 2002). A replicated study from Poland found the highest production of red mason bees per nest was from nesting materials of reed stems or wood."
}

tools_called.args: {"action_ids":["47","48","80"],"summary":"Several unintended negative consequences and limitations have been identified with the provision of artificial nest boxes for bees. Parasitism and predation are potential negative consequences of providing artificial nest boxes (47). Mortality rates from these causes have been measured at between 13% and 56% (47). Additionally, some nest box designs, such as those with plastic-lined holes or plastic/paper tubes, have been found to be less productive due to issues with parasitism or mould (47). Another unintended consequence is the occupation of nest boxes by non-native species, which in some cases, used the boxes more commonly than native bees (47).\n\nA significant limitation is the low uptake or occupancy rate of the nest boxes (48, 80). For bumblebees, very low uptake rates of 0-2.5% have been recorded in several UK trials (48, 80). Similarly, some trials for solitary bees have shown no occupancy at all (47). Furthermore, for bumblebees, there is no evidence to suggest that providing nest boxes has a positive effect on their populations (48). Commonly marketed wooden surface or above-ground nest boxes are not the most effective designs for bumblebees and have resulted in occupancy rates as low as 0-1.5% in some UK studies (48).","query":"What unintended negative consequences or limitations have been identified when providing artificial nest boxes for bees?"}

query: What is the most effective design for an artificial nest box intended for bumblebees?
relevant_summary: Several different types of artificial nest boxes have been shown to be acceptable to bumblebees, including wooden or brick and tile boxes at ground surface, underground tin, wooden or terracotta boxes and boxes attached to trees [48]. However, wooden surface or above-ground nest boxes are not the most effective design [48]. While some studies have shown 10-40% occupancy for these types of boxes [48], more recent trials have found very low occupancy rates of 0-2.5% [48] and 2% or less [80]. Nest boxes that are entirely buried 5-10 cm underground, with a 30-80 cm long entrance pipe, are generally the most effective, with studies finding occupancy rates between 6% and 58% [48]. Despite this, there is no evidence for the effects of providing nest boxes on bumblebee populations [48].

query: What are the documented effects on wild bees of introducing agri-environment schemes on European farmland?
relevant_summary: Four replicated trials in Europe showed that the diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees were enhanced on land managed under agri-environment schemes (24). However, two replicated trials in the UK found that bumblebee populations were not enhanced on a wider landscape scale on farmland managed under these schemes (24). Additionally, four replicated trials in Europe found no enhancement in the number of bees or bee species on land under agri-environment schemes (24). A UK study on invertebrates indicated that agri-environment scheme prescriptions had a local but not a landscape-scale effect on bee numbers (700). Of ten studies on invertebrates in three European countries, six showed that agri-environment schemes maintained or had little to no effect on some invertebrates, while five studies found increases in abundance or species richness of some invertebrates (700).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"agri-environment schemes for wild bees in Europe"}

Twenty-six studies from four European countries (including one UK systematic review and three European reviews) looked at the effects of agri-environment schemes on birds. Twenty-four studies (including one systematic review, six site comparisons and nine reviews) found increases in population size, density or more favourable population trends of some or all birds studied on sites with agri-environment schemes compared to non-scheme sites (some of these differences were seasonal). Eleven studies (including one systematic review and four reviews) found negative or no effects. One UK study found higher numbers of some birds where higher tier management was in place, another UK study found no difference between Entry Level or Higher Level Stewardship Scheme fields. One study from the Netherlands found that not all agri-environment scheme agreements were sited in ideal locations for black-tailed godwit.
Eleven studies from five European countries (including three replicated paired site comparisons and two reviews) looked at the effects of agri-environment schemes on plants. Three studies found increases in plant species richness in areas with agri-environment schemes, two found decreases. A replicated site comparison study from Estonia found higher flower abundance on farms with agri-environment schemes in two out of four areas. Four studies (including two replicated site comparisons and a review) from the UK looked at the effects of agri-environment schemes on mammals. One study found positive effects, three studies found mixed effects in different regions or for different species.
Three of the studies above found higher numbers of wildlife on land before agri-environment schemes were introduced. However two studies collecting baseline data found no difference in the overall number of birds or earthworms and soil microorganisms between areas with and without agri-environment schemes.

query: How does sowing agricultural forage plants on field margins compare to sowing native wildflower mixes in terms of benefits for bumblebees?
relevant_summary: Three replicated trials found that a mix of agricultural forage plants, including legumes, attracts a higher number of bumblebees than a perennial wildflower mix in the first year (18). However, one small replicated trial indicated that common long-tongued bumblebee species showed a strong preference for perennial wildflower seed mixes over annual forage plant mixes (19). Five replicated trials in the UK demonstrated that uncropped field margins sown with wildflowers supported a greater abundance of foraging bumblebees, and in three of those trials, a higher species richness, when compared to cropped field edges, grassy margins, or naturally regenerated uncropped margins (19). The value of margins with agricultural legume plants to bumblebees has been found to degrade, requiring them to be re-sown every few years (18). For both types of mixes, perennial leguminous herbs have been shown to be important forage sources for bumblebees, particularly for long-tongued species (18, 19). Generally, 41 studies found that flower strips positively influenced invertebrate numbers, increasing abundance, species richness, or both (442).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"sowing agricultural forage plants vs native wildflower mixes for bumblebees"}

{
  "action_id": "442",
  "action_title": "Plant nectar flower mixture/wildflower strips",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

A total of 80 individual studies have in some way investigated the effects of flowering strips on biodiversity. Sixty-four individual studies show some benefits to one or more wildlife groups.


Sixty-five individual studies reported the effects of flower strips on invertebrates. Of these, fifty reported positive effects. Forty-one studies from eight European countries (including five reviews and twenty-three replicated controlled studies, of which one randomized and two site comparisons) found evidence that flower strips had a positive influence on invertebrate numbers with increased abundance, species richness/diversity, or both. Ten studies (nine replicated of which two controlled) found invertebrates visited or foraged on flower strips but did not specify increases/decreases in numbers. Two studies found effects on ground beetles other than changes in numbers. One replicated controlled study showed that ground beetles were more active or had enhanced feeding/reproductive conditions in flower strips. A review found flower strips supported ground beetle species that were rarely found in crops. Fifteen studies reported mixed or negative effects of flower strips on invertebrates. Six studies found no significant effects.


Twenty-one studies looked at the effects of flower strips on plants. Sixteen studies from seven European countries (including ten replicated controlled studies of which one randomized) found evidence that flower strips had higher plant cover, number of flowers, diversity, and species richness. One review found flower strips benefited plants but did not specify how. Four studies found negative or no effects of flower strips on the number or diversity of plant species. Five studies described the effects of different margin establishment or management techniques on plants.


Seven studies investigated birds and wildflower strips. Four replicated, controlled studies from Switzerland and the UK (two of which were randomized) and one review of European studies found evidence that plots sown with a wildflower or legume seed mix had a positive influence on birds. Flower strips attracted more birds or bird species and the number of birds using flower strips increased over time. Eurasian skylarks preferentially foraged in, and nested in or near, sown weed patches and were less likely to abandon their territories when they included sown weed patches. However one replicated trial in Switzerland found barn owls avoided sown wildflower areas. Two winter recording periods of the same replicated, controlled study in the UK found there were not more bird species or individuals on wildflower plots compared to control margins.


All five studies investigating the effects of wildflower strips on small mammals (four replicated studies from Switzerland and one review of studies from north-western Europe) found evidence that small mammals benefit from strips sown with wildflowers or flowers rich in pollen and nectar, with increases in abundance, density and species richness. One replicated study from Switzerland reported that most common vole home ranges and core regions of their territories were found within a wildflower strip.


Nineteen studies (of which eight replicated, controlled) reported positive effects on biodiversity of sowing specific plant species including phacelia, and/or other plant species such as borage and red clover. Three replicated studies (two also controlled) found negative impacts or no effects on biodiversity of sowing phacelia."
}

query: What factors, such as diet and social parasitism, have been shown to affect the success of captive-rearing and reintroducing bumblebee colonies?
relevant_summary: The pollen diet of captively reared bumblebees has been shown to influence reproductive success (50). In one trial, colonies fed on freshly frozen pollen produced larger queens that survived better and produced larger colonies than those fed on dried, frozen pollen (50). Additionally, two replicated trials demonstrated that Bombus terrestris workers can produce more offspring when fed types of pollen with a higher protein content (50). For colonies placed in the field, one trial in Canada found that supplementary feeding improved the reproductive success of captive-reared colonies but did not reduce their parasite load, while another trial in the USA found no increase in colony productivity with supplementary feeding (52). Rates of social parasitism by cuckoo bees in colonies released to the wild are variable, with two replicated trials in Canada and the UK finding high rates of 25-66% and 79% respectively (52). The UK trial showed that parasitism was reduced by placing colonies in landscapes with intermediate rather than very high nectar and pollen availability, and late, rather than early in the season (52). Five other replicated trials reported no social parasites (52).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"factors affecting success of captive-rearing and reintroducing bumblebee colonies diet social parasitism"}

{
  "action_id": "50",
  "action_title": "Rear declining bumblebees in captivity",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
We have captured 22 trials from 13 countries documenting captive rearing of bumblebee colonies by confining mated queens alone (eight trials), with one or more bumblebee workers (seven trials), honey bee workers (one trial), male bumblebee pupae (three trials) or following anaesthetisation with CO2 (four trials). One trial found that over four years of artificial rearing, Bombus terrestris queens gradually decreased in weight.
Three trials have tried to rear North American bumblebees now declining or thought to be declining. Two induced spring queens of the half-black bumblebee B. vagans to rear adults in captivity, one trial induced queen yellow-banded bumblebees B. terricola (attempted in all three trials) and red-belted bumblebees B. rufocinctus (only attempted in one trial) to rear adults in captivity. All three trials tried to rear the yellow bumblebee B. fervidus and in all cases the queens laid eggs but the larvae died before becoming adults. One trial found the same pattern for the rusty-patched bumblebee and the American bumblebee B. pensylvanicus. One study reports rearing the large garden bumblebee B. ruderatus, a Biodiversity Action Plan species in the UK.
Two trials have reported laboratory rearing of a pocket-making bumblebee, the Neotropical B. atratus.
Three replicated trials demonstrated that the pollen diet of captively reared bumblebees influences reproductive success. In one trial, buff-tailed bumblebee B. terrestris colonies fed on freshly frozen pollen produced larger queens that survived better and produced larger colonies themselves than colonies fed on dried, frozen pollen. Two replicated trials demonstrated that B. terrestris workers can produce more offspring when fed types of pollen with a higher protein content.
Two replicated experiments showed that an artificial light regime of eight hours light, 16 hours darkness, can reduce the time taken for artificially reared queen B. terrestris to lay eggs, relative to rearing in constant darkness.
We have captured two replicated trials examining the effect of different artificial hibernation regimes in B. terrestris. One showed that hibernation of queens at 4-5°C for 45 days enhanced egg-laying and colony formation rates, but hibernated queens produced smaller colonies than non-hibernated queens. The second showed that queens should weigh more than 0.6 g (wet weight) and be hibernated for four months or less to have a good chance of surviving."
}
